description: From Middle English ebbe, from Old English ebba (“ebb, tide”), from Proto-West Germanic *abbjā, from Proto-Germanic *abjô, *abjǭ, from Proto-Germanic *ab (“off, away”), from Proto-Indo-European *apó.
See also West Frisian ebbe, Dutch eb, German Ebbe, Danish ebbe, Old Norse efja (“countercurrent”), Old English af. More at of, off.

examples: All the sea lying betweene, is verie ebbe, full of shallowes and shelves

entries.meaning: The receding movement of the tide.
examples: The boats will go out on the ebb.
Thus all the treasure of our flowing years, / Our ebb of life for ever takes away.

entries.meaning: (especially in the phrase 'at a low ebb') A low state; a state of depression.
examples: A "lowest ebb" implies something singular and finite, but for many of us, born in the Depression and raised by parents distrustful of fortune, an "ebb" might easily have lasted for years.

entries.meaning: A European bunting, the corn bunting (Emberiza calandra, syns. Emberiza miliaria, Milaria calandra).

verbs.description: ebb (third-person singular simple present ebbs, present participle ebbing, simple past and past participle ebbed)

examples: The dying man's strength ebbed away.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) to fish with stakes and nets that serve to prevent the fish from getting back into the sea with the ebb
